parts:
John Ousterhout and Tcl/TK: The Birth of a Revolutionary Scripting Language

In 1985, John Ousterhout, a computer science professor at the University of California, Berkeley, set out to solve a problem that had been plaguing software developers for years: the trade-off between performance and productivity. Ousterhout believed that developers should not have to choose between using a high-level language that was easy to use but slow, or a low-level language that was fast but difficult to use. He set out to create a new system-independent scripting language that would offer the performance benefits of system programming languages with the productivity of high-level languages.

That language was Tcl (pronounced "tickle"), short for Tool Command Language. It was designed to be a simple, yet powerful, scripting language that could be used to create scripts that would run on any system. Tcl was released in 1988, and it quickly gained popularity among developers who were tired of the limitations of existing scripting languages.

One of the key features of Tcl was its ability to integrate with other programming languages. This allowed developers to use Tcl as a glue language to connect different components of their software systems. Tcl also came with a graphical user interface toolkit called Tk (short for Toolkit), which made it easy for developers to create GUI applications.

Python and Javascript: The Rise of Scripting Languages

While Tcl was gaining popularity in the early 1990s, two other scripting languages were also on the rise: Python and Javascript.

Python was created by Guido van Rossum in the late 1980s, and it was released in 1991. Like Tcl, Python was designed to be a simple, yet powerful, scripting language. It was also designed to be easy to read and write, with a syntax that emphasized code readability.

Javascript was created by Brendan Eich in 1995, and it was designed to be a scripting language for the web. Javascript was used to add interactivity to web pages, such as dropdown menus and pop-up windows. It quickly became one of the most popular scripting languages on the web.

Both Python and Javascript were influenced by Tcl in different ways. Python borrowed some of Tcl's features, such as its emphasis on code readability, while Javascript borrowed Tcl's ability to integrate with other programming languages.

Conclusion

In the 1980s and 1990s, a revolution was brewing in the world of software development. John Ousterhout and Tcl/TK were at the forefront of this revolution, creating a new system-independent scripting language that offered the best of both worlds: the performance benefits of system programming languages and the productivity of high-level languages.

Today, Tcl is still widely used, particularly in the areas of embedded systems, networking, and scientific computing. Python and Javascript have also become incredibly popular, and they continue to evolve and innovate. Together, these scripting languages have changed the face of software development, making it easier and more accessible for people around the world.

parts: Where does appscript Logger store the logs
flattened: Where does appscript Logger store the logs

parts:
The `Logger` service in Google Apps Script is used to log messages, warnings, and errors in your script. The logs generated by the `Logger` service are stored in the "Execution Transcript" view, which can be accessed from the script editor by clicking on the "View" menu and selecting "Execution Transcript".

The "Execution Transcript" view shows a chronological list of all the logs generated during the execution of your script. You can filter the logs by severity level (info, warning, error) using the dropdown menu on the top right corner of the view.

By default, logs are retained for 30 days after they are generated, after which they are automatically deleted. However, you can also download the logs as a CSV file by clicking on the "Download" button on the top right corner of the view. This can be useful if you need to save the logs for auditing or debugging purposes.

By default, logs are retained for 30 days after they are generated, after which they are automatically deleted. However, you can also download the logs as a CSV file by clicking on the "Download" button on the top right corner of the view. This can be useful if you need to save the logs for auditing or debugging purposes.

parts: where is the view menu in the appscript editor
flattened: where is the view menu in the appscript editor

parts:
The "View" menu in the Google Apps Script editor is located in the top menu bar of the editor window. Here are the steps to access it:

1. Open the Google Apps Script editor by clicking on "Tools" > "Script editor" in your Google Sheets, Docs, or Slides document.
2. Once the editor window opens, you should see a menu bar at the top of the window.
3. Click on the "View" menu in the menu bar. This will display a dropdown menu with a list of options, including "Execution transcript", "Logs", and "Debug logs".

You can select any of these options to access different views and logs related to your Google Apps Script project. For example, selecting "Execution transcript" will show you a list of all the executions of your script, along with the logs generated during each execution.
